entry.title: graphite: Disallow Skia write access for bottom left origin surfaces
entry.content:
Graphite won't support rendering to bottom left origin surfaces so

disallow it at the shared image level now that we've removed all usage

on the client side.



This CL removes the last known usage of bottom left origin surfaces:

1) CopyOutputRequest result textures and corresponding client usage.

2) CompoundImageBacking tests.

entry.title: Add a no-fullscreen aura window resize behaviour
entry.content:
Currently there is no way to specify when a window should not be able

to go into fullscreen. This change adds that.



This should have no functional change. The flag is currently coupled

with CanMaximize to prevent accidentally introducing a regression with

the split. A followup CL will break the coupling.

entry.title: [CrOS Cellular] Add APN configuration changed notification.
entry.content:
During APN migration, if the custom APN was last unsuccessful

in connecting when the flag was off, and the details of the custom

APN are preserved in the disabled state, a notification indicating

this will surface.



Note that strings are not final and will be added in a later CL

after string discussion.



When the user clicks on the notification, it will disappear, and

settings will open in the APN subpage containing the disabled APN.



See go/create-apn-config-changed-notification.

Screenshot: https://screenshot.googleplex.com/4qeStFAZWZ8QXg7



Bug: b/162365553

Test: unit_test ApnMigrator* and manual test with special verizon sim

entry.title: [Extensions] Create service worker event dispatch to renderer metric.
entry.content:
Extensions.Events.DispatchToSendToRenderer.ExtensionServiceWorker

Extensions.Events.DispatchToSendToRenderer.ExtensionEventPage

Extensions.Events.DispatchToSendToRenderer.ExtensionBackgroundPage



This metric measures the time it takes from the start of event dispatch

in the event router (browser) until the event is dispatched to the

renderer. It is meant to help assess what share of pre-renderer

(vs post-renderer) time is spent when dispatching events.

entry.title: sensors: Deliver error notifications to suspended sensors too.
entry.content:
https://w3c.github.io/sensors/#focused-area only talks about how focus

influences whether sensor readings are available, but nothing is

mentioned about not firing "error" events.



If something goes wrong on the platform side and it needs to notify

clients (such as Blink) that an error has occurred, that should happen

regardless of whether the sensor is suspender or not -- in most cases,

Blink will disconnect from the //services side and fire an "error"

event.



Remove the DCHECK in SensorImpl::OnSensorError(), which should have

always been the intended behavior -- PlatformSensor::NotifySensorError()

does not have the check for client.IsSuspended() that

PlatformSensor::NotifySensorReadingChanged() does.



Bug: 1278377

entry.title: ServiceWorkerAutoPreload for the main resource
entry.content:
Here is the flow explaining how major methods are called per race

results.

https://docs.google.com/presentation/d/13A54OUqaBPrgkIQZE3a3CnhT3pe3C70j07HCisjNZlI/edit#slide=id.g2753dd0eed3_0_0



This CL adds ServiceWorker auto preload behavior to the main resource.

It dispatches the network request by using RaceNetworkRequest mechanism,

but always waits for the result from the fetch handler.



The fetch handler will resolve fetch(e.request) with the response from

the network request. If the fetch handler response is fallback, the

in-flight network request will be used as a fallback request.



This change is behind the flag.



Bug: 1472634

entry.title: graphite: Allow forcing Graphite with --skia-graphite-backend flag
entry.content:
Interpret the presence of --skia-graphite-backend flag, with or without

a value, as forcing the use of Graphite in all cases. This allows cc/viz

pixel tests to run without ANGLE Metal which doesn't seem to be enabled

merely by enabling the DefaultANGLEMetal feature flag, probably because

we default to Swiftshader GL on tests (without --use-gpu-in-tests).



Also, add the missing dawnProcSetProcs call in layer_tree_test.cc to

match what pixel_test.cc does.



In the future, we probably want to run these tests with VkSwiftshader,

but use Metal for now since we're only planning on enabling it on M1

Macs.

entry.title: Always save Lacros logs in /var/log/lacros for test images
entry.content:
Previously, if Lacros crashed and was restarted in the session

after being initially prelaunched at login screen, logs would

(confusingly) be directed to the cryptohome. Similarly for many

tast tests that run Lacros directly in the session without going

through the login screen.



This change makes it so that when the Lacros prelaunching flag is

enabled, Lacros logs always go to /var/log/lacros in test images,

independently of whether the current instance of Lacros was

launched at login screen or not.



This makes the location of the Lacros logs more predictable.



BUG=1473589

TEST=Tested on Eve test image

entry.title: Reland "AbortSignal: Deflake memory tests"
entry.content:
This is a reland of Ic395066fb034d7dbfcca77a4b62752a1ffe5c4dc. This

changes gc({execution: 'async'}) to use postTask() + gc() to avoid

tripping leak detection (see crbug.com/1474629). It also splits the

TaskSignal abort memory tests in two to decrease chance of hitting a

timeout (rel bots showed ~3s, which is 50% of timeout budget).



Original CL's Description:



> AbortSignal: Deflake memory tests

>

> The abort signal memory tests rely on a single synchronous gc() to

> collect signals and trigger finalization registry callbacks, which has

> become flaky on Mac (worker tests only). The implementation was changed

> recently, but the tests were reliably passing from 8/10 -- 8/16. The

> change to use a per-Worker microtask queue in crrev.com/c/4781406 may

> have caused the tests to start flaking (timing lines up, reverting it

> locally fixes things), but it's not clear how that's affecting GC.

>

> Testing on a Mac locally I found the third test fails fairly reliably,

> but attempts to debug it (heap snapshots w/ GC removed, console logs,

> tracing, etc.) removed the flakiness. Adding a second gc() reliably

> fixes the third test, but other tests still fail (less often).

>

> This CL refactors the tests to speculatively fix the flakes:

> 1. Run GC asynchronously. It's possible something on the stack is

> holding onto the signal. This probably needs to be done anyways for

> conservative stack scanning (other tests have been similarly

> refactored to use.

> 2. Because of (1), change tests to use WeakRef instead of finalization

> registry. This is cleaner and will fail before the timeout, giving

> more insight into failures.

> 3. Do multiple rounds of gc. I found doing gc() multiple times fixed

> test 3, but that could have also just changed timing. But blink

> unit tests run GC in a loop, so it seems reasonable to do this to

> ensure collection occurs in case multiple cycles are needed.

>

> Locally on mac, the memory tests pass with these changes with

> --repeat-each=1000, and I didn't find any flakes on the Mac bots.

>

> Bug: 1473373

> Change-Id: Ib6a65ce52372c5220126b490aee79e8f4b33e183

> Reviewed-on: https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/4787951

> Commit-Queue: Scott Haseley

entry.title: Add touch selection session touch count metrics.
entry.content:
PM would like to know the number of touch down movements users need to

make to successfully place a cursor or select text, as a measure of the

overall "effort" required for touch selection.



Try to measure this by adding a metric for the number of touch down

events that occur in a "successful" touch selection "session":



- The session starts from the first touch down that activates touch

selection, e.g. a tap or long press which triggers touch handles.



- Count the touch down events targeted to the touch selection context

window or popup menu.



- Record the touch down count if the session is ended successfully,

by a text editing key event or menu command. Don't record the touch

down count if the session ends unsuccessfully, e.g. if window

closed, timed out after 10s (since the user intent has probably

changed in these situations).



Only record for content for now, maybe add a corresponding metric for

views later.



Design doc: go/cros-touch-text-editing#heading=h.nmwbq0ix2t8q

entry.title: vaapi/test: Change H265 decoder to decode frames on demand
entry.content:
Currently the platform H265 decoder decodes every frame in the stream

and then releases them one by one. This causes a lot of memory pressure

and thrashes heavily. This CL changes the behavior to decode the

frames on demand and release the memory when it is no longer needed.



Before Fix on Nissa:

1080p: 324.901714 FPS

2160p: 67.960468 FPS



With Fix on Nissa:

1080p: 11282.106605 FPS

2160p: 3245.634293 FPS



Bug: b/290212133

Test: Tested by running

video.PlatformDecodingPerf.vaapi_hevc* and video.PlatformDecoding.vaapi_hevc* on a Nissa and a Rex.

entry.title: [gc] Make ComputedStyle & friends GarbageCollected.
entry.content:
This patch moves ComputedStyle (and sub-objects) onto the gc-heap for

security reasons.



The performance profile of this patch is "complex". :).



For the motionmark-benchmark (non-PGO as so many signatures change due

to this patch) we roughly have (lower%, upper%):



+------------- +-----------------+----------------+

| MotionMark | M1[1] | Win10[2] |

+--------------+-----------------+----------------+

| Leaves | -2.26%, -1.72% | -3.30%, -2.12% |

| Design | +3.30%, +9.27% | -2.67%, -0.53% |

| Suites | -5.38%, -2.21% | |

| Canvas Lines | +2.26%, +2.80% | +0.33%, +1.91% |

| Images | | -1.68%, -0.29% |

| Canvas Arcs | | +0.10%, +0.52% |

+--------------+-----------------+----------------+

[1] https://pinpoint-dot-chromeperf.appspot.com/job/11d3186f960000

[2] https://pinpoint-dot-chromeperf.appspot.com/job/17b0242d960000



This is (broadly speaking) a net-win (M1 ~+0.5%, Win10 ~neutral).



Speedometer is also (broadly speaking) a net-win.

M1[3]: -0.28%, +0.13%, p-value: 0.47 (neutral)

Win10[4]: -0.68%, -0.15%, p-value: 0.00 (positive)



[3] https://pinpoint-dot-chromeperf.appspot.com/job/162b373f960000

[4] https://pinpoint-dot-chromeperf.appspot.com/job/11530dd8560000



There should be no functional behaviour change.

entry.title: Introduce external display timeout deferral for lock screen
entry.content:
When a Thunderbolt-enabled Chromebook is connected to a Thunderbolt

display with the lid closed and on the lock/login screen, the display

enters DisplayPort alternate mode. A subsequent unlock/login causes

the display to switch to Thunderbolt alternate mode.



This switch leads to a transient disconnection of connected displays.

The PowerEventObserver, seeing no displays, immediately throws the

system back to the lock screen, which is a bad UX.



So, introduce a timer which starts on unlock and login, and during

which, the number of displays going to 0 *does not* generate a lock

screen. This gives enough time for the display stack to re-enumerate

the displays. At the end of the timeout, we can attempt to lock

the screen again (if the system state allows it).



The value of the timer timeout is taken from cros-config, and is the

same as what is used by Chrome OS power_manager to control similar

behaviour, but for suspend/resume instead of the lock screen.



Devices which don't have the cros-config setting will remain unaffected

by this change.



Bug: b/280752163

Change-Id: I839869f8f4e82c62ed25e5041d6956e76aa1f522

Reviewed-on: https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/4654993

entry.title: [headless] Avoid using PostTask in Posix shutdown handler
entry.content:
The previous implementation of Posix shutdown signal handlers called

PostTask from the context of the signal handler which is not safe. This

CL fixes this by routing signal through a pipe to an IO thread where it

is safe to post tasks.

entry.title: snap-group: Group cycle item creation and removal
entry.content:
This cl creates `GroupContainerView` for snap group in window

cycle view, which will be the direct child view of the

`mirror_container_`, which will be used as the focus target

for snap group.

This cl also handles window destruction, for free forms windows

the `WindowCycleItemView` will be removed. For group item,

however, we will only remove the child view that represents

the destroying window. With the newly added `TryRemovingItem`,

`WindowCycleView` would know whether to clean up the corresponding

list or not.

entry.title: [infra] Make per-builder outputs location configurable.
entry.content:
In preparation for switching the dev builders to use the chromium recipe

(which is bootstrapped), this makes the location of per-builder output

files configurable. This will allow for configuring a different root

directory for the dev builder's outputs to avoid possible collisions and

keeping the configuration of the tracked files simple.



A new chrome_browser_infra lib has been added to contain functions for

performing such global configurations. A separate lib was created

rather than making it part of the bootstrap lib because it will also

be used for generating GN args and tests in starlark.



In order to be able to provide global configuration values such as the

per builders outputs directory, a new singleton node type was added to

the nodes lib. Generators are unable to get values from lucicfg.vars, so

the singleton nodes allow for working around this limitation to provide

configuration that can be set once and read by the generator.



Bug: 955020

entry.title: Shutdown process manager after resetting the context core
entry.content:
This CL moves the step of shutdown the process manager to the end of the

shutdown so the object that needs to have a valid browser context can

remove itself from observing other modules properly. For example, it

would allow the ServiceWorkerHidDelegateObserver destructor to remove

itself properly from the HidDelegate using a valid browser context.

entry.title: p13n: Remove AmbientProviderImpl pending updates
entry.content:
Removed has_pending_updates_for_backend_ to simplify the code in

AmbientProviderImpl.



The current implementation pauses any updates to the backend until after

the current update finishes. Instead, cancel current updates and send

the new update.



This maintains the invariant that only one update request is in

flight at a time. One main implementation difference is that there is no

barrier to sending update requests.



BUG=b:296114840

TEST=unit_tests *AmbientProviderImpl*

TEST=browser_tests *PersonalizationApp*Ambient*



Change-Id: I25bf64c996a430979b13d9fc9fe8c4779c66290d

entry.title: Reland "[Survey] Modularize upstream SurveyController (3/5)"
entry.content:
This reverts commit b2ff683cdc96362e17230ced361404284672b61a.



Reason for revert: Fix by leaving SurveyController as an empty class.



All the upstream references to SurveyController is replaced with the new interface getting through SurveyControllerProvider. This moves part of the implementation in upstream (5/5) so the downstream tests does not crash.



Original change's description:

> Revert "[Survey] Modularize upstream SurveyController (3/5)"

>

> This reverts commit e93a110916f62f221da16103c205330353cdf2bc.

>

> Reason for revert: builder is broken

> https://ci.chromium.org/ui/p/chrome/builders/ci/chromium-internal-arm-builder

>

> Original change's description:

> > [Survey] Modularize upstream SurveyController (3/5)

> >

> > Remove the non-interface instance of SurveyController created by AppHooks, so the downstream override can be removed.

> >

> > Note that the internal build target //chrome/browser/ui/android/hats/internal:controller_java is temporarily added as DEP to //chrome/android/BUILD.gn - this is temporarily, and once SurveyClientImpl is complete, the deps will be removed.

> > SurveyController will be removed in a follow up patch, so there's no plans adding test to expand the test coverage.

entry.content:

entry.title: Consolidate test GetAllWebContents implementations
entry.content:
Several chrome layer tests iterate through all WebContents by more or

less copying the implementation of WebContentsImpl::GetAllWebContents.

We now provide a test utility which makes use of the content internal

method.



Note that we don't expose a GetAllWebContents method publicly for

production code due to layering concerns.



There is also a similar call site within content which we convert to

just use the internal method.



This also lets us remove a number of incidental uses of

RenderViewHost::From.

entry.title: Reland "ozone/drm: Leave Link Status=Bad when a Connector Has no Modes"
entry.content:
This is a reland of commit a3bb1cf7641c234901a8385c4b1fcf91c493dd5c



The original change was reverted because querying DRM for each connector

within every modeset test and atomic modeset was very expensive and

introduced a significant regression for each display configuration

attempt in ChromeOS.



The reland solves this issue by caching the connection state and number

of modes per connector in the connector's property cache, and later

using it to figure whether or not a connector's link-status should be

reset to GOOD.



Original change's description:

> ozone/drm: Leave Link Status=Bad when a Connector Has no Modes

>

> Currently, Chrome always resets a connector's link status to GOOD before

> modesetting. This is important when a connector is reported by DRM to

> have some operational bandwidth and modes, since a connector that was

> previously marked in a bad state must be reset in order to successfully

> atomic commit in the future.

>

> However, if link-training fallback attempts have exhausted all possible

> bit-rate combinations and still failed to train the connector, it should

> have all its modes pruned and marked in a bad state.

>

> Chrome already prunes all connectors that are marked connected and have

> no modes [1]. This ensures that connectors that are in a bad state are

> ignored by higher layers of Chrome (e.g. Ash/Lacros) and no modeset or

> page flips are attempted on them (simply because a display abstraction

> will not not exists for the pruned connector).

>

> This patch ensures that the connectors that are ignored by Chrome are

> also left in a bad state when the other connectors are being modeset.

>

> [1] https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/main:ui/ozone/platform/drm/common/drm_util.cc;l=415-418

>

> Bug: b:296579659

> Test: ozone_unittests && display_unittests

> Change-Id: I4f66b39a00b9a4fa45cee10f6cdc24185b927c62

> Reviewed-on: https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/4795333

> Reviewed-by: Daniel Nicoara

> Commit-Queue: Gil Dekel

> Cr-Commit-Position: refs/heads/main@{#1185999}

entry.title: Automatically annotate LeakedDanglingUntraged ExperimentalAsh pointers [12/N]
entry.content:
This patch is:

- Automated. See [automation] section.

- Not affecting users, only Chrome's CQ. See [no-op] section.



Note: This one is about the LeakedDanglingUntriaged. The automation

process is different from the previous 11 patches.



Context:

--------

@bartekn is going to remove the `ExperimentalAsh` raw_ptr annotation.

This was a performance experiment to enable/disable MiraclePtr on a

subset of new pointers added for ChromeOS ash (non-lacros).



Before removing it, he needs to enable it by default in code. Enabling

MiraclePtr for them, causes the DanglingPointerDetector to be enforced.

To pass the CQ, we need to annotate pre-existing dangling pointer with

`DanglingUntriaged`. After enabling ExperimentalAsh feature, it won't be

allowed anymore for those pointers to become dangling.



Automation:

-----------

1. Enable the `PartitionAllocBackupRefPtrForAsh` feature flag.

2. Instrument raw_ptr: https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/4506773

3. Run all the gtests. See https://docs.google.com/document/d/1AMMERcqy0eafFWopUCHYsIKIKEp3J8DFxqW9UIbzIHo

4. Annotate manually every LeakedDanglingUntriaged ptr found.

5. Cherry-pick the patch created from (5)

6. Run `git cl format`



no-op:

------

The DanglingPointerDetector is not enabled against users. It only

affects tests and chromium developers.



AX-Relnotes: n/a.

Cq-Include-Trybots: luci.chrome.try:chromeos-betty-pi-arc-chrome

Bug: chromium:1441101

Change-Id: I39de3261d1275f0fe94f3ad16aac508ff4f91fd3

Reviewed-on: https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/4797734

Reviewed-by: Daniel Cheng

Auto-Submit: Arthur Sonzogni

Owners-Override: Daniel Cheng

Commit-Queue: Arthur Sonzogni

Cr-Commit-Position: refs/heads/main@{#1186810}

entry.title: Automatically annotate dangling ExperimentalAsh pointers [11/N]
entry.content:
This patch is:

- Automated. See [automation] section.

- Not affecting users, only Chrome's CQ. See [no-op] section.



This split is about the new dangling pointer that got added the last few

days.



Context:

--------

@bartekn is going to remove the `ExperimentalAsh` raw_ptr annotation.

This was a performance experiment to enable/disable MiraclePtr on a

subset of new pointers added for ChromeOS ash (non-lacros).



Before removing it, he needs to enable it by default in code. Enabling

MiraclePtr for them, causes the DanglingPointerDetector to be enforced.

To pass the CQ, we need to annotate pre-existing dangling pointer with

`DanglingUntriaged`. After enabling ExperimentalAsh feature, it won't be

allowed anymore for those pointers to become dangling.



Automation:

-----------

1. Enable the `PartitionAllocBackupRefPtrForAsh` feature flag.

2. Apply the 'annotator' CL: https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/4474553

3. Run all the gtests. See https://docs.google.com/document/d/1AMMERcqy0eafFWopUCHYsIKIKEp3J8DFxqW9UIbzIHo

4. Concatenate all the output_*, `filter`, `sort -nr`, `uniq`.

5. Run https://github.com/ArthurSonzogni/chrome-dangling-ptr-apply-edit

6. Run `git cl format`

7. Cherry-pick the patch created from (5)



no-op:

------

The DanglingPointerDetector is not enabled against users. It only

affects tests and chromium developers.



AX-Relnotes: n/a.
